key_points: US President-elect Joe Biden plans a mostly virtual inauguration amid the COVID-19 pandemic to keep America safe.
Biden's inauguration aims to minimize crowd sizes, contrasting with Trump's 2017 inauguration claims of record attendance.
The 2021 inauguration events will be scaled-down, including a reimagined parade and limited in-person attendance.
Only 1,000 people are expected to attend the swearing-in ceremony, significantly fewer than previous inaugurations.
The traditional Inaugural Luncheon has been cancelled due to the pandemic.
Donald Trump falsely claimed his 2017 inauguration had the largest attendance ever, but estimates suggested about 500,000 attendees.
Barack Obama's 2009 inauguration had an unofficial turnout of 1.8 million, considered the largest in history.
The federal government stopped making official estimates of crowd sizes for large gatherings in Washington due to controversies over accuracy.
Biden's inauguration will be noted with an asterisk in history books due to its unique, pandemic-induced circumstances.
Ronald Reagan's second inauguration in 1985 also faced adjustments due to dangerous weather conditions.
spokespersons: Sean Spicer (Former White House Press Secretary)
Roy Blunt (Missouri Republican Senator, Chairman of the JCCIC)
